(See `extrusion` property) The scaled sketch is then transformed into 3D by moving it along the z-axis by 0.0313 units without rotation. (See `extrusion` property) The resulting shape is a cylindrical object with a flat top and bottom, and a curved side. The object is centered and has a uniform width throughout its length. The height of this part is 0.0312, and the width and length are both 0.75. **Instructions for Creating the Second Intermediate CAD Part** **Shape:** A cylindrical object with a flat top and bottom, and a curved side. The object is centered and has a uniform width throughout its length. The process for creating the second part is similar to the first. Begin by creating a new coordinate system in the same position as the first, with no rotation. For the sketch, draw a circle centered at (0.375, 0.375) with a radius of 0.375. This circle forms the top face of the part and will be the basis of the 3D model. (See `sketch` property) The sketch must then be scaled by a factor of 0.75. (See `extrusion` property) However, instead of moving the sketch along the z-axis, this time the sketch should be moved along the negative z-axis by 0.0313 units. (See `extrusion` property) The resulting shape is another cylindrical object with a flat top and bottom, and a curved side. The object is centered and has a uniform width throughout its length. The height of this part is 0.0312, and the width and length are both 0.75. The final CAD model is the combination of these two intermediate CAD parts.</description>
